content: Limitation on disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to certain countries. Section 5302 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to limit disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to foreign countries not in compliance with IMF commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot exceed $500,000,000 for international rescue plans unless the country meets IMF reform commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury must ensure that foreign countries receiving disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund are meeting their commitments to the International Monetary Fund regarding economic, market access, and financial reforms. The aggregate amount of all expenditures, loans, obligations, or guarantees made through the stabilization fund for a specific country within a 6-month period will be considered to determine if it exceeds the limitation imposed. The Secretary of the Treasury must ensure foreign countries receiving funds from the Exchange Stabilization Fund comply with commitments made to the IMF for financial assistance packages. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress semiannually on monitoring foreign governments in Asia for compliance with IMF commitments. The report includes actions taken by the US Executive Director at the IMF and the Treasury Department to enforce these commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury reports to Congress semiannually on monitoring foreign governments in Asia for compliance with IMF commitments and describes actions taken to enforce these commitments. SEC. 3. Monitoring the effects of the Asian financial crisis on the United States and other economies. The Commerce Department, in coordination with the U.S. Trade Representative, will monitor Asian countries receiving financial assistance to ensure they comply with international agreements on market access. Reports will be submitted to Congress every two months until assistance is terminated, including progress on resolving trade disputes. The progress in resolving trade disputes and compliance with international agreements by Asian countries receiving financial assistance will be monitored. Reports to Congress will include updates on issues with Korea's trade barriers, Korea's obligations under a trade agreement, and Indonesia's compliance with ending its "National Car" program. The 1995 Korea Memorandum of Understanding on trade in motor vehicles will be monitored for compliance. Reports will include Indonesia's adherence to ending its "National Car" program and the implementation of IMF reforms on corporate governance and structure. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor third country actions to accept increased Asian exports and report to Congress on a bimonthly basis until financial assistance for each Asian country is terminated. The Secretary of Commerce, along with other government officials, will take action to open markets for Asian countries receiving financial assistance. The Commerce Department will monitor exports to the US from these countries for any significant increases due to currency fluctuations or subsidies. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor exports to the US from Asian countries receiving financial assistance for any significant increases due to currency fluctuations, subsidies, dumping, or transshipment. Reports will be provided to Congress every two months until assistance is terminated, taking appropriate action if dumping or subsidization harms US industries. Consultation with industry representatives will be conducted. The Secretary of Commerce will consult with import-sensitive US industries to monitor and report on the effects of financial assistance provided to Asian countries. Reports will be submitted annually to Congress to assess the impact on trade relations and market conditions. SEC. 4. FULL ENFORCEMENT OF TRADE LAW REMEDIES. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study with import-sensitive US industries to determine the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. The study will address rapid fluctuations in exchange rates to prevent undermining US antidumping laws. The Secretary of Commerce will determine the treatment of currency devaluations and financial assistance in Asian countries under US antidumping and countervailing duty laws. This includes addressing fluctuations in exchange rates to prevent undermining US antidumping laws. The Secretary of Commerce will report to Congress on the study regarding countervailing duty laws and subsidies received in the past within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. The provisions of this Act will expire 8 years after its enactment.
